conclusion: Analyze the forces acting on the oil droplets before and after the voltage U is applied.
Analyze the motion of droplets with no voltage applied.
When no voltage is applied, both droplets A and B are falling with a uniform velocity v1. The force exerted by the air resistance on each droplet is f = k m0^(1/3) v1.
Since they are moving uniformly, the net force on each droplet must be zero. Therefore, the gravitational force equals the air resistance force: mg = k m0^(1/3) v1.
When a voltage U is applied, an electric field is created between the plates, and a force proportional to the charge Q of the droplets acts on them.
For droplet B, the electric force is upward and equal to the downward force due to the weight of B minus the upward air resistance force.
Since B moves upward with a uniform velocity v2 after some time, the net force on B is zero, so the electric force balances the weight and the air resistance: Q U/d = m0 g - k m0^(1/3) v2.
After merging, the total mass of the new droplet is 2m0, and the new velocity after merging is not specified but remains constant.
The new air resistance force is f_new = k (2m0)^(1/3) v'.
Since the new droplet is moving with a uniform velocity, the net force is again zero: 2m0 g - f_new = 0.
The proportionality constant k is k = 2^(2/3) m0^(-1/3) g.
